thread.title: Bank Trading Desks Are On a Roll

author: Allison Prang
title: Bank Trading Desks Are On a Roll
text:
0 COMMENTS Trading desks at the largest banks have started off the year on a high note.
The five U.S. banks with large trading desks finished reporting their first-quarter financial results this week, and one of the star performers was equities desks. Those units–where individual stocks, indexes and exchange-traded funds are bought and sold–saw double-digit percentage revenue increases, helped by volatility in the markets so far this year.
In a numerical stroke of serendipity for the banks, equities trading revenue rose 38% at three separate institutions: Goldman Sachs Group , Bank of America and Citigroup The same metric at Morgan Stanley rose 27% and at JPMorgan Chase & Co. rose 26%.

In fixed income divisions, which are typically larger than equities businesses, trading performance was mixed.

At Goldman Sachs, fixed income, currencies and commodities trading revenue rose 23% off a disappointing 2017 first quarter result. At Morgan Stanley, fixed-income trading climbed 9% and at JPMorgan, it rose 8%. Trading fell 13% at Bank of America and 7% at Citigroup.
Trading desks overall aren’t as big as they used to be. Last year , the five largest banks had about $70 billion in trading revenue. While that was an improvement from recent years, it’s still down from almost $100 billion in 2009.
